5.80.text:
When I was in Goa, maybe five 
years ago, a little girl came up

10.97.text:
who was one of the children

and so obviously she saw her mother go to the

And she came up to me and she said,

26.30.text:
Like that and I said, “We, you know, 
we’re just talking about how to be happy.”

And she just looked at me 
like it was the weirdest thing.

Like, “Why do you need to talk about that?”

And you see this is the point: we have 
trained ourselves to be miserable

46.67.text:
—that's conventional life. And we train 
ourselves and we accept the training that says,

54.40.text:
“We are not okay and we need 
to fix ourselves and we need to improve.”

And that training covers 
our entire experience.

So, even if we are very successful, 
what do we and everyone else look at

75.90.text:
What doesn't work; what was 
wrong; how can we improve it?

81.00.text:
It is never like, “Oh my God we are 
amazing, look what we have just done.

84.60.text:
Let's do something else.” It's just 
like picking it apart, analyzing it,

90.53.text:
I mean just talking about it makes

And so, here in Balanced View 
you're given a very simple instruction.

102.77.text:
So, there's only one instruction that 
you need to or you're invited to practice.

But more importantly there's a very simple 
support structure that's easy to implement

115.43.text:
and use in the midst of your everyday life,

122.37.text:
You know, we have had enough of that. We have had 
enough of trying to change our lives

128.90.text:
And it also doesn't mean that you 
don't stop trying to change things.

141.03.text: So, that was a rhetorical question to myself.

146.00.text:
So, you see the point is, is that we've 
all tested this conventional approach to life

152.33.text:
whereby we believe that at some point 
in the future if we change something

156.57.text:
about our thoughts, emotions 
and circumstances we will feel okay.

Now of course, you know being 
healthy, having lots of friends,

166.50.text:
having more money, 
maybe having children

169.53.text:
—all of these things they do

173.23.text:
But all of you know—and I am 
sure many of you have achieved

176.33.text:
these things like this in your life, 
some of them or all of them

180.30.text:
You don't feel like you have 
arrived, you don't feel, “Okay, that's it.

184.07.text:
Now I can relax.” And 
that will never stop.

187.93.text:
So, that feeling that there is 
something missing will just continue.

192.07.text:
And for me that was just like a perpetual

198.90.text:
Like, “What?” You know, “I 
just feel on edge all of the time

203.00.text:
even when things 
are going really well.”

206.33.text:
And we're so amazing 
as human beings,

210.80.text:
to be able to put up with such 
relentless negativity and still function

215.73.text:
even slightly, you 
know, it’s amazing.

221.87.text:
You know, we're totally amazing 
and also we know deep down

225.60.text: that there is something that we can rely on.

230.67.text:
We don't know what it is, 
especially, obviously

233.53.text:
when we haven't been introduced to 
open intelligence, but you see this is another

236.90.text:
laughable thing about 
seeking for the nature of reality.

242.17.text:
So, I spent twenty years looking 
for something and I didn't have a clue

245.27.text:
what I was looking for. I had lots of 
names for it but I had no idea what it was.

250.73.text:
So, even if it came and bit me on 
the ass I wouldn't know what it was.

255.33.text:
You know, it's just you have 
to know what something is

258.60.text:
in order to find it, that's

265.80.text:
we can introduce ourselves to what we 
describe as “open intelligence” very easily

270.40.text:
and that is just to stop thinking.

274.13.text:
You can stop describing, stop thinking and what do 
you recognize in your experience when you do so?

282.10.text:
Now, the thoughts will all come back, 
you know, maybe it's a sensation.

287.30.text:
So, it's only a split second, a short 
moment that you stop thinking

290.97.text:
and you can recognize 
something in your experience.

293.97.text:
So, in the Balanced View training 
we call this “open intelligence.”

298.13.text:
It's clear, it's open, it's an undeniable 
but maybe subtle presence.

304.07.text:
Now so, stop thinking again, 
identify open intelligence

307.77.text:
and can you locate it 
anywhere? Where is it?

311.33.text:
I don't know! Where is it? It's 
like, “Is it inside? Is it outside?

316.50.text:
Is it everywhere? Is it nowhere?” It's just 
like, it's very, very difficult to pin down,

320.83.text:
but it's easy to experience 
and this is key.

323.53.text:
It's the experience of the 
recognition of open intelligence

326.77.text:
that we are interested in the Balanced 
View Training, not in pigeon holing it

331.93.text:
and being able to fit it in with what you 
already know on a conventional level.

337.43.text:
And so, the introduction to open intelligence
—the stopping thinking—anyone can do it,

343.30.text:
and it's very clear that you 
already have open intelligence.

346.50.text:
It's not, you're not getting it. It's 
just a simple acknowledgment.

351.30.text:
So, the instruction to stop 
thinking isn't the practice,

354.83.text:
that's just to identify open 
intelligence in your experience.

357.60.text:
Because like I said, the 
thoughts will come back;

360.13.text:
these sensations will immediately come 
back. So, the practice of short moments

364.10.text:
is just to relax and identify that 
presence whenever you remember.

369.37.text:
And you'll find very quickly that whether you 
are thinking or not thinking that presence is there.

374.33.text:
And so, this is the amazing thing about 
short moments: your life doesn't need to change

378.37.text:
in order to practice short 
moments. It's your data,

382.57.text:
and so the term “data” in the Balanced 
View training is just a simple umbrella term

387.67.text:
we use to describe everything we 
can experience as human beings,

392.20.text:
so: thoughts, emotions, circumstances, 
people, places, things.

398.07.text:
We just term the whole 
collection “data”.

401.97.text:
And although that might seem a bit strange 
and a bit neutralizing in the beginning,

406.77.text:
it's greatly soothing because
what it means is it doesn't matter

410.17.text:
how complicated you 
think your thoughts are.

414.00.text:
And when I came to this Training I had what 
I thought was a terribly complicated negative life.

420.17.text:
I was depressed, I had panic 
attacks, I was overweight.

423.80.text:
And then I had nearly thirty years of books 
and trainings and things that I'd read

433.40.text:
that proved why I was depressed 
and the reasons for this so

437.79.text: millions of facts just rattling around

441.03.text: that seemed to need to be sorted out

443.22.text:
in order for me to feel okay. 
So, it was very, very complicated.

446.08.text:
But when you apply this simple 
algorithm of short moments,

449.83.text:
that whole tsunami of negative data just boils 
down to that simple choice in each moment,

457.13.text:
“I can recognize open intelligence 
or not.” Which is like,

460.43.text:
“Wow, that’s genius. Why 
didn't I think of that before?”

465.67.text:
So, it wasn't complicated. You know 
my life was in fact very, very powerful

470.27.text:
and a very powerful motivation 
to practice this one instruction.

475.80.text:
So, in each moment you 
have the power to either

480.27.text:
rest and relax as open intelligence 
for a brief moment, or not.

483.83.text:
So, the actual instruction, the only instruction 
is: short moments of open intelligence,

491.47.text:
So, whatever's occurring for you, 
wherever you are, in each moment,

496.80.text:
basically whenever you remember, relax and 
just acknowledge the presence of open intelligence.

506.73.text:
And what you'll find is 
that, that subtle presence

518.00.text:
that you identify when we just did 
that little experiment with stopping thinking,

522.53.text:
it just starts to pervade everything. So, 
all of this negative data and even positive data,

528.70.text:
rather than being constricting and 
maybe feeling like it's trapped in your chest

533.77.text:
or in your throat—that was 
my experience—it's not.

537.83.text:
And what you start to see is 
that, just like I said, when

543.60.text:
when you identify open intelligence in your 
experience and then you try and locate it,

549.00.text:
you can't actually pin it down, it's everywhere; 
it's nowhere; it's inside; it's outside.

555.33.text:
The experience of open intelligence 
it cannot be described adequately.

560.67.text:
But it's very easy to experience. But what 
you'll find is that is the quality of all data.

565.57.text:
So things like anger: it's not inside, it's 
not outside, it's everywhere, it's nowhere,

571.63.text:
it exists, it doesn't exist. “Oh 
my god! What's going on?”

575.97.text:
And it's very normal in the beginning for 
people to—I would say for the first few years

581.13.text:
and this again this was my experience—
to have certain data streams that seem like

585.23.text: they are never going to get resolved.

587.51.text:
Like, when they appear 
open intelligence goes out the window,

595.17.text:
I've shared this many times before 
but the solution to my anger before

598.37.text:
was to smash quite expensive 
pieces of equipment.

604.67.text:
I mean I would be lying if I said swinging a 
mouse around like this and smashing it in the wall

610.97.text:
didn't provide some relief, but it 
wasn't the solution to my anger.

617.33.text:
And basically, when I went back 
to the music store to get a new mouse

623.50.text:
maybe sometimes twice a week, the 
guy, the person that was serving me

630.67.text:
thought you know, “What's this 
guy doing with these mice?”

638.27.text:
And so, you know, the conventional 
approach to anger of either bottling it up

645.43.text:
until we explode or expressing it and 
smashing things or however it is,

651.10.text:
that provides temporary relief but usually 
it provides more problems than it does solutions.

656.10.text:
So, don't worry if you just get 
carried away with anger—it's fine;

663.57.text:
and if it’s the same with 
jealousy or depression.

The great beauty of the practice 
of short moments is that

673.53.text:
all you need to do is to practice

677.80.text:
And gradually at some point

683.30.text:
and you'll recognize open intelligence

because directly you will be angry

693.00.text:
and it's the most amazing thing. And 
when that occurs for you it might be

698.37.text:
a little, it will be quite strange

When that happened for me, and 
it did happen with anger I was just like,

711.40.text:
So I didn't act in the same old ways,

But then, as I got used to that, 
then it enabled me to act,

719.67.text:
if something made me angry

722.20.text:
I could act from that space

725.67.text:
And sometimes the response is 
exactly the same as if I was acting,

730.50.text:
you know, in a conventional way, 
“What do you think you are doing?

736.97.text: I am being very polite here.

741.00.text:
But most of the time I just

744.30.text:
has nothing to do with anything other

747.97.text: And it is just the most amazing thing.

750.13.text:
And so, this is definitely something 
you can apply with collaboration,

754.37.text:
whether it's with 
yourself or with others.

757.13.text:
You know, by relying on open 
intelligence you're instantly,

764.17.text:
like, so intimately connected it's like your

And to be privileged enough 
to be able to work with people

779.23.text:
who are relying on open intelligence

784.07.text:
And I can really say from the heart

789.30.text:
who are relying on open intelligence

792.50.text:
on a conventional level about 
the projects that you are working on.

796.00.text:
Because that open hearted 
desire to be of benefit

799.67.text:
and just to support the 
other people in the project

803.33.text:
firstly allows them to 
learn very, very quickly.

But in terms of me when I think

when, prior to Balanced View, if someone

816.97.text:
I would just reject it out of hand even

820.97.text: and better than mine, you know?

“Well to accept that on board then

833.03.text:
and that my ideas are rubbish.”

836.87.text:
ridiculous, disempowering 
way to be with people.

And now it's the most incredible gift

845.70.text:
And to start to see that sometimes when

852.50.text:
the opposite of how you would do them

856.33.text: that sometimes in a really amazing way.

859.70.text:
It just allows for collaboration and

868.87.text:
the really, really limiting ways that we

and be in a group with them and work

883.53.text:
and assumptions are diametrically

887.77.text:
You know, you would never, well I

892.80.text:

899.47.text:
Because that would be the only thing that

And of course it's all my data, but

908.70.text:
the beneficial potency in 
my hatred and anger.

912.47.text: It's not about me changing the other person.

915.34.text:
It's just me seeing that, 
that is the beneficial potency of

919.17.text:
really, really wanting to 
cooperate and help humanity.

923.60.text:
And we see this on a individual level

928.77.text:
We have an exact working model of 
the entire human race in our experience.

933.90.text:
And when we stop trying to change things—our 
own thoughts and emotions and circumstances

939.87.text:
—and we just leave them be, 
all that we recognize is

942.60.text:
our own perfection and then we can't 
but help to see this in other people.

946.43.text:
And then if we meet somebody who does 
have a different set of belief systems to us,

952.87.text:
there's immediately a ground of communication,

961.37.text:
This is the way humanity is going to find

969.50.text:
Nobody’s going to ever agree with you.

973.17.text:
that has the same data that you do. So, how on

And quite clearly for the last, well

986.37.text:
—I don't know how long it is—ten

992.73.text: The way we try to solve problems

998.63.text:
between large groups of human beings is exactly

People don't agree with you, you fight them

So, really don't underestimate the

And just to finish, so there's the one

Short moments of open intelligence, 
repeated many times,

become continuous—you're

So, the first one is the

there's media, free media.

on the internet and

you'll be able to have

open intelligence trainer you can write to at

And then the community is,

is it shows that this

This is where it's needed, in 
your normal everyday life

1153.70.text:
with your friends and your

and then by default open people

it's just the most wonderful
